Eight individual samples taken at 3-hour intervals were collected from the effluent discharge pipe.  1L nalgene vessels were filled for analysis of inorganic chemicals. Two 50 ml glass vials with teflon caps were filled for analysis of organic chemicals.  Samples were analyzed using EPA methods by R.J. Lee Group Laboratories.

Water samples are collected in new 250-mL polyethylene bottles. The bottles are rinsed three times with stream water before the sample is collected. The samples are sent to ALLARM within two weeks of collection, where they are acidified using 5 ml of concentrated trace element grade nitric acid, and refrigerated (Method EPA 200.2). Samples are then sent to an accredited laboratory (Chemical Solutions, 273 Mulberry Drive, Suite 9, Mechanicsburg, PA) where they are analyzed for barium and strontium using a Perkin-Elmer ICP-MS and EPA Method 200.8.

Samples collected following ALLARM Protocol. Analyzed at IsleChem LLC.

Sampling followed USGS Reston Chlorofluorocarbon Laboratory protocol for dissolved gases. Samples and QA/QC standards were analyzed using a Hewlett Packard model 5890 GC (http://water.usgs.gov/lab/dissolved-gas/lab/analytical_procedures/)
During purging of well, field measurements made using a Orion Star A329 portable multiparameter meter.
Sample collected in polyethylene bottles, unfiltered, after purging.  Analyzed colorimetrically by titration (HACH Company, 2012b).
Sample collected in polyethylene bottles, unfiltered, after purging. Alkalinity measured using a digital titrator with sulfuric acid (HACH Company, 2008).
Sample collected in polyethylene bottles, unfiltered, after purging. Analyzed colorimetrically by titration using a test kit with a minimum reporting lime of 10 mg/L (HACH Company, 2012a).

Well purged before collection. Samples collected in two 40 mL glass vials. Samples were shipped to ALS Environmental in Middletown, PA for analysis. The constituents analyzed were dissolved methane, propane, ethane, and ethene concentrations using the headspace method (RSK-175). Towards the end of the sampling portion of the study, the laboratory analyses also included n-butane and isobutane.
Analyzed at Isotech Laboratories using a custom-configured Carle Gas Chromatograph (GC), based on the ASTM D1945 method.
Analyzed using an offline preparation system and duel inlet mass spectrometer at Isotech Laboratories.

Collected in 30 mL capped class serum vials with no head space and preserved with CuCl2 to prevent microbial degradation. Determined on a ThermoQuest Finnigan Delta Plus XL continuous-flow gas ratio mass spectrometer.
Collected in 30 mL glass scintillation vials with no head space. Measurements compiled on a Finnigan Delta S gas-source isotope ratio mass spectrometer.
Oakton 110 series pH meter and Ross Combination electrode (precision, +/-0.01 pH units)

Samples filtered through a 0.45 micrometer nylon filter, collected in 30 mL HDPE bottle with no headspace and preserved with concentrated HNO3. Chemistry determined by Perkin Elmer Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectrometer (ICP-OES) Model Optima 5300 DV.
Samples filtered through a 0.45 micrometer nylon filter, collected in 30 mL HDPE bottle with no headspace. Alkalinity was measured by the Gran-Alk titration method within 12 hours of sampling.
Samples filtered through a 0.45 micrometer nylon filter, collected in 30 mL HDPE bottle with no headspace. Chemistry determined  by a Dionex Ion Chromatograph Model ICS-3000 with an AS23 column.

Collected in 250 ml glass bottles and spiked with KOH biocide. Analyzed by the USGS Chlorofluorcarbon Laboratory using a Hewlett Packard model 5890 gas chromatograph with a Flame Ionization Detector with a minimum reporting limit of 1.0 micrograms per liter (?g/L) and precision of ±0.5 ?g/L.

Collected in 1 L Isotech bottles, with a benzyl alkonium chloride biocide capsul (~0.5 mL/L).  Analyzed at The Pennsylvania State University using a Hewlett Packard model 5830 gas chromatograph and Flame Ionization Detector with a minimum reporting limit of 0.1 ?g/L and precision of less than or equal to (?) 2 percent.

Collected in 500 mL bottles with no biocide, sampled and analyzed within 5 days at The Pennsylvania State University using a Hewlett Packard model 5830 gas chromatograph and Flame Ionization Detector with a minimum reporting limit of 0.1 ?g/L and precision of less than or equal to (?) 2 percent. Collected 500mL for testing. Did not use biocide for analysis. The analysis was done directly after collection.

The approach used to estimate mean areal precipitation (MAP) for each of the MOPEX basins is essentially the same as used for gauge-only MAP estimation in the National Weather Service River Forecast System (NWSRFS). The undelying interpolation procedure uses an inverse distance algorithm. The MAP procedure can be found in the MOPEX US Data Documentation. The link is included.

The procedure to estimate mean areal temperature involved first estimating mean areal maximum and minimum daily temperature. Then if temperature values during the day are needed, the procedure suggested by Parton and Logan (1981) to estimate hourly tempertures from daily maximum and minimum was used.

Potential Evaporation estimates based on data from the NOAA Evaporation Atlas. This atlas contains maps of average annual and May-October free water surface potential evaporaton. The NOAA Evaporation Atlas Maps were derived by analysis
